/-- The subgroup has finite index -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H : Subgroup G} [self : Subgroup.FiniteIndex H], Subgroup.index H ≠ 0 :=

/-- The topological closure of a normal subgroup is normal. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace G] [inst_1 : Group G] [inst_2 : TopologicalGroup G] (N : Subgroup G)
  [inst_3 : Subgroup.Normal N], Subgroup.Normal (Subgroup.topologicalClosure N) :=

/-- In a group that satisfies the normalizer condition, every maximal subgroup is normal -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G), NormalizerCondition G → IsCoatom H → Subgroup.Normal H :=

/-- Elements of disjoint, normal subgroups commute. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H₁ H₂ : Subgroup G),
  Subgroup.Normal H₁ → Subgroup.Normal H₂ → Disjoint H₁ H₂ → ∀ (x y : G), x ∈ H₁ → y ∈ H₂ → Commute x y :=

/-- The topological closure of a normal additive subgroup is normal. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace G] [inst_1 : AddGroup G] [inst_2 : TopologicalAddGroup G] (N : AddSubgroup G)
  [inst_3 : AddSubgroup.Normal N], AddSubgroup.Normal (AddSubgroup.topologicalClosure N) :=

/-- Elements of disjoint, normal subgroups commute. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] (H₁ H₂ : AddSubgroup G),
  AddSubgroup.Normal H₁ → AddSubgroup.Normal H₂ → Disjoint H₁ H₂ → ∀ (x y : G), x ∈ H₁ → y ∈ H₂ → AddCommute x y :=

/-- A subgroup has index two if and only if there exists `a` such that for all `b`, exactly one
of `b * a` and `b` belong to `H`. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H : Subgroup G}, Subgroup.index H = 2 ↔ ∃ a, ∀ (b : G), Xor' (b * a ∈ H) (b ∈ H) :=

/-- The normal closure of s is a normal subgroup. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {s : Set G} [inst : Group G], IsNormalSubgroup (Group.normalClosure s) :=

/-- The normal closure of a set is a subgroup. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (s : Set G), IsSubgroup (Group.normalClosure s) :=

/-- Any normal subgroup is either `⊥` or `⊤` -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [self : IsSimpleGroup G] (H : Subgroup G), Subgroup.Normal H → H = ⊥ ∨ H = ⊤ :=

/-- A subgroup contains the group's 1. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G), 1 ∈ H :=

/-- Two subgroups are equal if they have the same elements. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H K : Subgroup G}, (∀ (x : G), x ∈ H ↔ x ∈ K) → H = K :=

/-- A subgroup is closed under division. -/
theorem ∀ {M : Type u_1} {S : Type u_2} [inst : DivInvMonoid M] [inst_1 : SetLike S M] [hSM : SubgroupClass S M] {H : S}
  {x y : M}, x ∈ H → y ∈ H → x / y ∈ H :=

/-- A subgroup is closed under multiplication. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G) {x y : G}, x ∈ H → y ∈ H → x * y ∈ H :=

/-- The additive subgroup has finite index -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] {H : AddSubgroup G} [self : AddSubgroup.FiniteIndex H], AddSubgroup.index H ≠ 0 :=

/-- The normal closure of s is the smallest normal subgroup containing s. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {s t : Set G}, IsNormalSubgroup t → s ⊆ t → Group.normalClosure s ⊆ t :=

/-- Subgroups of torsion groups are torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.IsTorsion G → ∀ (H : Subgroup G), Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- A subgroup is closed under inverse. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G) {x : G}, x ∈ H → x⁻¹ ∈ H :=

/-- The normal closure of `s` is a normal subgroup. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {s : Set G}, Subgroup.Normal (Subgroup.normalClosure s) :=

/-- The composition of two group homomorphisms is a group homomorphism. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : Group α] [inst_1 : Group β] {f : α → β},
  IsGroupHom f → ∀ {γ : Type u_1} [inst_2 : Group γ] {g : β → γ}, IsGroupHom g → IsGroupHom (g ∘ f) :=

/-- Every index 2 subgroup of a group is normal. -/
theorem

/-- Subgroups of torsion-free groups are torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree G → ∀ (H : Subgroup G), Monoid.IsTorsionFree { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Direct products of torsion free groups are torsion free. -/
theorem ∀ {η : Type u_1} {Gs : η → Type u_2} [inst : (i : η) → Group (Gs i)],
  (∀ (i : η), Monoid.IsTorsionFree (Gs i)) → Monoid.IsTorsionFree ((i : η) → Gs i) :=

/-- Direct products of additive torsion free groups are torsion free. -/
theorem ∀ {η : Type u_1} {Gs : η → Type u_2} [inst : (i : η) → AddGroup (Gs i)],
  (∀ (i : η), AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree (Gs i)) → AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree ((i : η) → Gs i) :=

theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G],

theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [hN : Nontrivial G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree G → ¬Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

theorem ∀ (G : Type u_1) [inst : CommGroup G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree (G ⧸ CommGroup.torsion G) :=

/-- Finite groups are torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Finite G], Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- Torsion groups are closed under extensions. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : Group G] {N : Subgroup G} [inst_1 : Group H] {f : G →* H},
  N = MonoidHom.ker f → Monoid.IsTorsion H → Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ N } → Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- Subgroups of torsion groups are torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.IsTorsion G → ∀ (H : Subgroup G), Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- A nontrivial torsion group is not torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [hN : Nontrivial G], Monoid.IsTorsion G → ¬Monoid.IsTorsionFree G :=

/-- Quotienting a group by its additive torsion subgroup yields an additive torsion free group. -/
theorem ∀ (G : Type u_1) [inst : AddCommGroup G], AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree (G ⧸ AddCommGroup.torsion G) :=

/-- A nontrivial torsion-free additive group is not torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] [hN : Nontrivial G], AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree G → ¬AddMonoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- If a group exponent exists, the group is torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.ExponentExists G → Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- Subgroups of additive torsion groups are additive torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G], AddMonoid.IsTorsion G → ∀ (H : AddSubgroup G), AddMonoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Additive torsion groups are closed under extensions. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : AddGroup G] {N : AddSubgroup G} [inst_1 : AddGroup H] {f : G →+ H},
  N = AddMonoidHom.ker f → AddMonoid.IsTorsion H → AddMonoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ N } → AddMonoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- A nontrivial additive torsion group is not torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] [hN : Nontrivial G], AddMonoid.IsTorsion G → ¬AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree G :=

/-- Finite additive groups are additive torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] [inst_1 : Finite G], AddMonoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- The group exponent exists for any bounded torsion group. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G],
  Monoid.IsTorsion G → Set.Finite (Set.range fun g => orderOf g) → Monoid.ExponentExists G :=

/-- Torsion submonoids are torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : CommMonoid G], Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ CommMonoid.torsion G } :=

/-- Quotienting by the torsion submodule gives a torsion-free module. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_2} {M : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_2 : Module R M],
  Submodule.torsion R (M ⧸ Submodule.torsion R M) = ⊥ :=

/-- Every free group is torsion free. -/
theorem
choices: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [hF : IsFreeGroup G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree G

  "∀ (n p : ℕ), Finset.card (Finset.filter (fun x => p ∣ x) (Finset.Ioc 0 n)) = n / p",
  "isProp": true,

 {"theorem":

 {"theorem":

  "isProp": true,

 {"theorem":
  "∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedRing α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] {x y : α},\n  1 ≤ x → 1 < y → ∃ n, y ^ n ≤ x ∧ x < y ^ (n + 1)",

prompt_cons:
/-- Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization -/
theorem Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ≠ 0} :=

/-- If a small natural number is divisible by a larger natural number,
the small number is zero. -/
theorem ∀ {a b : ℕ}, a ∣ b → b < a → b = 0 :=

/-- Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, (∀ (a : ℕ), a ∣ m ↔ a ∣ n) ↔ m = n :=

/-- A prime natural number is prime in `ℤ[i]` if and only if it is `3` mod `4` -/
theorem ∀ (p : ℕ) [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], Prime ↑p ↔ p % 4 = 3 :=

/-- The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [dec_irr : (p : Associates α) → Decidable (Irreducible p)]
  [inst_1 : UniqueFactorizationMonoid α] [dec : DecidableEq α] [dec' : DecidableEq (Associates α)] {a p : Associates α},
  Irreducible p →
    ∀ [inst_2 : (n : ℕ) → Decidable (a ∣ p ^ n)] {n : ℕ} (h : a ∣ p ^ n),
      a = p ^ Nat.find (_ : ∃ n, (fun n => a ∣ p ^ n) n) :=

/-- Infinitely many natural numbers are equal to `d` mod `n`. -/
theorem ∀ {n : ℕ}, n ≠ 0 → ∀ (d : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (m : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, m ≡ d [MOD n] :=

/-- Exactly `n / p` naturals in `[1, n]` are multiples of `p`. -/
theorem ∀ (n p : ℕ), Finset.card (Finset.filter (fun e => p ∣ e + 1) (Finset.range n)) = n / p :=

/-- Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, (∀ (a : ℕ), m ∣ a ↔ n ∣ a) ↔ m = n :=

/-- A natural number `m` divides the sum `m + n` if and only if `m` divides `n`. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, m ∣ m + n ↔ m ∣ n :=

/-- The only numbers with empty prime factorization are `0` and `1` -/
theorem ∀ (n : ℕ), Nat.factorization n = 0 ↔ n = 0 ∨ n = 1 :=

/-- A natural number `m` divides the sum `n + m` if and only if `m` divides `n`. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, m ∣ n + m ↔ m ∣ n :=

/-- All composite numbers are Fermat pseudoprimes to base 1. -/
theorem ∀ {n : ℕ}, 1 < n → ¬Nat.Prime n → FermatPsp n 1 :=

/-- For any positive `k : ℕ` there are infinitely many primes `p` such that `p ≡ 1 [MOD k]`. -/
theorem ∀ {k : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → Set.Infinite {p | Nat.Prime p ∧ p ≡ 1 [MOD k]} :=

/-- The multiplicity of prime `p` in `p` is `1` -/
theorem ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → ↑(Nat.factorization p) p = 1 :=

/-- Exactly `n / p` naturals in `(0, n]` are multiples of `p`. -/
theorem ∀ (n p : ℕ), Finset.card (Finset.filter (fun x => p ∣ x) (Finset.Ioc 0 n)) = n / p :=

/-- The only prime divisor of positive prime power `p^k` is `p` itself -/
theorem ∀ {p k : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → Nat.Prime p → List.toFinset (Nat.factors (p ^ k)) = {p} :=

/-- No zero divisors. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [self : CanonicallyOrderedCommSemiring α] {a b : α}, a * b = 0 → a = 0 ∨ b = 0 :=

/-- A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4` -/
theorem ∀ {n : ℕ}, n % 2 = 1 ↔ n % 4 = 1 ∨ n % 4 = 3 :=

/-- The factors of `n` are the prime divisors -/
theorem ∀ (n : ℕ), List.toFinset (Nat.factors n) = Finset.filter Nat.Prime (Nat.divisors n) :=

/-- Every x greater than or equal to 1 is between two successive
natural-number powers of every y greater than one. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedRing α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] {x y : α},
  1 ≤ x → 1 < y → ∃ n, y ^ n ≤ x ∧ x < y ^ (n + 1) :=

/-- Every natural number greater than `1` is divisible by a prime number. -/
theorem
choices: ∀ (n : ℕ), 1 < n → ∃ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p ∧ p ∣ n

/-- Finite groups are torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Finite G], Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- Subgroups of torsion-free groups are torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree G → ∀ (H : Subgroup G), Monoid.IsTorsionFree { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Quotienting a group by its torsion subgroup yields a torsion free group. -/
theorem ∀ (G : Type u_1) [inst : CommGroup G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree (G ⧸ CommGroup.torsion G) :=

/-- A nontrivial torsion-free group is not torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [hN : Nontrivial G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree G → ¬Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- Direct products of torsion free groups are torsion free. -/
theorem ∀ {η : Type u_1} {Gs : η → Type u_2} [inst : (i : η) → Group (Gs i)],
  (∀ (i : η), Monoid.IsTorsionFree (Gs i)) → Monoid.IsTorsionFree ((i : η) → Gs i) :=

/-- Quotienting a group by its additive torsion subgroup yields an additive torsion free group. -/
theorem ∀ (G : Type u_1) [inst : AddCommGroup G], AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree (G ⧸ AddCommGroup.torsion G) :=

/-- Subgroups of additive torsion-free groups are additively torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G],
  AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree G → ∀ (H : AddSubgroup G), AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Torsion groups are closed under extensions. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : Group G] {N : Subgroup G} [inst_1 : Group H] {f : G →* H},
  N = MonoidHom.ker f → Monoid.IsTorsion H → Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ N } → Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- A nontrivial torsion-free additive group is not torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] [hN : Nontrivial G], AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree G → ¬AddMonoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- Subgroups of torsion groups are torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.IsTorsion G → ∀ (H : Subgroup G), Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Direct products of additive torsion free groups are torsion free. -/
theorem ∀ {η : Type u_1} {Gs : η → Type u_2} [inst : (i : η) → AddGroup (Gs i)],
  (∀ (i : η), AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree (Gs i)) → AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree ((i : η) → Gs i) :=

/-- A nontrivial torsion group is not torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [hN : Nontrivial G], Monoid.IsTorsion G → ¬Monoid.IsTorsionFree G :=

/-- A semisimple Abelian Lie algebra is trivial. -/
theorem ∀ (R : Type u) (L : Type v) [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : LieRing L] [inst_2 : LieAlgebra R L]
  [inst : LieAlgebra.IsSemisimple R L] [h : IsLieAbelian L], Subsingleton L :=

/-- A finite group of prime order is simple. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Group α] [inst_1 : Fintype α] {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  Fintype.card α = p → IsSimpleGroup α :=

/-- Finite additive groups are additive torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G] [inst_1 : Finite G], AddMonoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- A finite group of prime order is simple. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : AddGroup α] [inst_1 : Fintype α] {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  Fintype.card α = p → IsSimpleAddGroup α :=

/-- Additive torsion groups are closed under extensions. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : AddGroup G] {N : AddSubgroup G} [inst_1 : AddGroup H] {f : G →+ H},
  N = AddMonoidHom.ker f → AddMonoid.IsTorsion H → AddMonoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ N } → AddMonoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- If a finite group is the direct product of its Sylow groups, it is nilpotent -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [hG : Group G] [inst : Fintype G],
  ((p : { x // x ∈ (Nat.factorization (Fintype.card G)).support }) → (P : Sylow (↑p) G) → { x // x ∈ ↑P }) ≃* G →
    Group.IsNilpotent G :=

/-- The group exponent exists for any bounded torsion group. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G],
  Monoid.IsTorsion G → Set.Finite (Set.range fun g => orderOf g) → Monoid.ExponentExists G :=

/-- Quotienting by the torsion submodule gives a torsion-free module. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_2} {M : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_2 : Module R M],
  Submodule.torsion R (M ⧸ Submodule.torsion R M) = ⊥ :=

/-- A finite torsion-free group is trivial -/
theorem
choices: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Finite G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree G → Subsingleton G

 {"theorem":

 {"theorem":

 {"theorem":

 {"theorem":

 {"theorem": "∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Infinite α], Nonempty (Field α)",

 {"theorem":
  "∀ {K : Type u_2} {L : Type u_1} [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Field L] [inst_2 : Algebra K L] (S : IntermediateField K L)\n  {x y : L}, x ∈ S → y ∈ S → x * y ∈ S",

  "docString": "An intermediate field is closed under multiplication. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {K : Type u} [inst : Field K] (s : Subfield K) {x y : K}, x ∈ s → y ∈ s → x * y ∈ s",

 {"theorem":

 {"theorem":

/-- A finite field has prime power cardinality. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : Fintype α] [inst_1 : Field α], IsPrimePow (Fintype.card α) :=

/-- An intermediate field is closed under division. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u_2} {L : Type u_1} [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Field L] [inst_2 : Algebra K L] (S : IntermediateField K L)
  {x y : L}, x ∈ S → y ∈ S → x / y ∈ S :=

/-- A field is a valuation ring. -/
theorem ∀ (K : Type u) [inst : Field K], ValuationRing K :=

/-- A cyclotomic finite extension of a number field is a number field. -/
theorem ∀ (S : Set ℕ+) (K : Type w) (L : Type z) [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Field L] [inst_2 : Algebra K L] [h : NumberField K]
  [inst_3 : Finite ↑S] [inst : IsCyclotomicExtension S K L], NumberField L :=

/-- A subfield is closed under division. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u} [inst : Field K] (s : Subfield K) {x y : K}, x ∈ s → y ∈ s → x / y ∈ s :=

/-- A finite subgroup of the units of an integral domain is cyclic. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] (S : Subgroup Rˣ) [inst_2 : Finite { x // x ∈ S }],
  IsCyclic { x // x ∈ S } :=

/-- A linear ordered field that is a floor ring is archimedean. -/
theorem ∀ (α : Type u_1) [inst : LinearOrderedField α] [inst_1 : FloorRing α], Archimedean α :=

/-- A module over a division ring is noetherian if and only if it is finitely generated. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u} {V : Type v} [inst : DivisionRing K] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup V] [inst_2 : Module K V],
  IsNoetherian K V ↔ Module.Finite K V :=

/-- A finite subgroup of the unit group of an integral domain is cyclic. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_2} {G : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Finite G]
  (f : G →* R), Function.Injective ↑f → IsCyclic G :=

/-- A field extension is algebraic if it is finite. -/
theorem ∀ (K : Type u_1) (L : Type u_2) [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Field L] [inst_2 : Algebra K L]
  [inst_3 : FiniteDimensional K L], Algebra.IsAlgebraic K L :=

/-- All ideals in a division (semi)ring are trivial. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u} [inst : DivisionSemiring K] (I : Ideal K), I = ⊥ ∨ I = ⊤ :=

/-- The quotient of a ring by an ideal is a field iff the ideal is maximal. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] (I : Ideal R), Ideal.IsMaximal I ↔ IsField (R ⧸ I) :=

/-- In a finite field of characteristic `2`, all elements are squares. -/
theorem ∀ {F : Type u_1} [inst : Field F] [inst_1 : Finite F], ringChar F = 2 → ∀ (a : F), IsSquare a :=

/-- A field extension is integral if it is finite. -/
theorem ∀ (K : Type u_1) (L : Type u_2) [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Field L] [inst_2 : Algebra K L]
  [inst_3 : FiniteDimensional K L], Algebra.IsIntegral K L :=

/-- A normed division ring is a topological division ring. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : NormedDivisionRing α], TopologicalDivisionRing α :=

/-- Any infinite type can be endowed a field structure. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Infinite α], Nonempty (Field α) :=

/-- An intermediate field is closed under multiplication. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u_2} {L : Type u_1} [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Field L] [inst_2 : Algebra K L] (S : IntermediateField K L)
  {x y : L}, x ∈ S → y ∈ S → x * y ∈ S :=

/-- A subfield is closed under multiplication. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u} [inst : Field K] (s : Subfield K) {x y : K}, x ∈ s → y ∈ s → x * y ∈ s :=

/-- Any conditionally complete linearly ordered field is archimedean. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField α], Archimedean α :=

/-- A ring is Noetherian if and only if all its ideals are finitely-generated. -/
theorem ∀ (R : Type u_1) [inst : Semiring R], IsNoetherianRing R ↔ ∀ (I : Ideal R), Ideal.FG I :=

/-- Every finite division ring is a field. -/
theorem
choices: ∀ (K : Type u_1) [inst : DivisionRing K] [inst_1 : Fintype K], Field K

/-- Finite topological spaces are compact. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : Finite α], CompactSpace α :=

/-- The underlying topological space is compact. -/
theorem ∀ (self : CompHaus), CompactSpace ↑self.toTop :=

/-- A compact discrete space is finite. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : CompactSpace α] [inst : DiscreteTopology α], Finite α :=

/-- For any topological space `X`, its one point compactification is a compact space. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X], CompactSpace (OnePoint X) :=

/-- In a Noetherian space, all sets are compact. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace.NoetherianSpace α] (s : Set α), IsCompact s :=

/-- In a locally compact space, every compact set is contained in the interior of a compact set. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : LocallyCompactSpace α] {K : Set α},
  IsCompact K → ∃ K', IsCompact K' ∧ K ⊆ interior K' :=

/-- If `X` is a compact space, then any discrete quotient of `X` is finite. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] (S : DiscreteQuotient X) [inst_1 : CompactSpace X],
  Finite (Quotient S.toSetoid) :=

/-- The product of two compact spaces is compact. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_2 : CompactSpace α]
  [inst_3 : CompactSpace β], CompactSpace (α × β) :=

/-- In a locally compact space every point has a compact neighborhood. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : LocallyCompactSpace α] (x : α), ∃ K, IsCompact K ∧ K ∈ nhds x :=

/-- Every open cover of a paracompact space assumes a locally finite refinement. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [self : ParacompactSpace X] (α : Type v) (s : α → Set X),
  (∀ (a : α), IsOpen (s a)) → ⋃ (a : α), s a = Set.univ → ∃ β t x x, LocallyFinite t ∧ ∀ (b : β), ∃ a, t b ⊆ s a :=

/-- In a `T2Space`, every compact set is closed. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : T2Space α] {s : Set α}, IsCompact s → IsClosed s :=

/-- Convex hull of a finite set is compact. -/
theorem ∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : AddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : Module ℝ E] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace E]
  [inst_3 : TopologicalAddGroup E] [inst_4 : ContinuousSMul ℝ E] {s : Set E},
  Set.Finite s → IsCompact (↑(convexHull ℝ) s) :=

/-- In a locally compact space,
every neighbourhood of every point contains a compact neighbourhood of that same point. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [self : LocallyCompactSpace α] (x : α) (n : Set α),
  n ∈ nhds x → ∃ s, s ∈ nhds x ∧ s ⊆ n ∧ IsCompact s :=

/-- The one point compactification of a locally compact Hausdorff space is a normal (hence,
Hausdorff and regular) topological space. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : LocallyCompactSpace X] [inst_2 : T2Space X],
  NormalSpace (OnePoint X) :=

/-- The disjoint union of two compact spaces is compact. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_2 : CompactSpace α]
  [inst_3 : CompactSpace β], CompactSpace (α ⊕ β) :=

/-- In a compact space, the type of closed subsets is compact. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : EMetricSpace α] [inst_1 : CompactSpace α], CompactSpace (TopologicalSpace.Closeds α) :=

/-- Any continuous bijection of compact Hausdorff spaces is an isomorphism. -/
theorem ∀ {X Y : CompHaus} (f : X ⟶ Y), Function.Bijective ↑f → CategoryTheory.IsIso f :=

/-- A sequentially compact set in a uniform space is totally bounded. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : UniformSpace X] {s : Set X}, IsSeqCompact s → TotallyBounded s :=

/-- In a nonempty locally compact space, there exists a compact set with nonempty interior. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : LocallyCompactSpace α] [inst_2 : Nonempty α],
  Nonempty (TopologicalSpace.PositiveCompacts α) :=

/-- All hom spaces are finite dimensional. -/
theorem ∀ {k G : Type u} [inst : Field k] [inst_1 : Monoid G] (V W : FdRep k G), FiniteDimensional k (V ⟶ W) :=

/-- Every finite topological space is compact. -/
theorem

/-- Every graph homomorphism from a complete graph is injective. -/
theorem ∀ {V : Type u} {W : Type v} {G' : SimpleGraph W} (f : ⊤ →g G'), Function.Injective ↑f :=

/-- A group homomorphism is injective iff its kernel is trivial. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : Group α] [inst_1 : Group β] {f : α → β},
  IsGroupHom f → (Function.Injective f ↔ ∀ (a : α), f a = 1 → a = 1) :=

/-- Any surjective endomorphism of a Noetherian module is injective. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} {M : Type u_2} [inst : Ring R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_2 : Module R M]
  [inst_3 : IsNoetherian R M] (f : M →ₗ[R] M), Function.Surjective ↑f → Function.Injective ↑f :=

/-- Any injective endomorphism of an Artinian module is surjective. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} {M : Type u_2} [inst : Ring R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_2 : Module R M]
  [inst_3 : IsArtinian R M] (f : M →ₗ[R] M), Function.Injective ↑f → Function.Surjective ↑f :=

/-- An additive group homomorphism is injective if its kernel is trivial. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : AddGroup α] [inst_1 : AddGroup β] {f : α → β},
  IsAddGroupHom f → (Function.Injective f ↔ ∀ (a : α), f a = 0 → a = 0) :=

/-- On a finite-dimensional space, an injective linear map is surjective. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u} {V : Type v} [inst : DivisionRing K] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup V] [inst_2 : Module K V]
  [inst_3 : FiniteDimensional K V] {f : V →ₗ[K] V}, Function.Injective ↑f → Function.Surjective ↑f :=

/-- Any injective polynomial map over an algebraic extension of a finite field is surjective. -/
theorem ∀ {ι : Type u_1} {K : Type u_2} {R : Type u_3} [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Finite K] [inst_2 : CommRing R]
  [inst_3 : Finite ι] [inst_4 : Algebra K R],
  Algebra.IsAlgebraic K R →
    ∀ (ps : ι → MvPolynomial ι R),
      (Function.Injective fun v i => ↑(MvPolynomial.eval v) (ps i)) →
        Function.Surjective fun v i => ↑(MvPolynomial.eval v) (ps i) :=

/-- Any injective endomorphism of an Artinian module is bijective. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} {M : Type u_2} [inst : Ring R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_2 : Module R M]
  [inst_3 : IsArtinian R M] (f : M →ₗ[R] M), Function.Injective ↑f → Function.Bijective ↑f :=

/-- Any surjective endomorphism of a Noetherian module is bijective. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} {M : Type u_2} [inst : Ring R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_2 : Module R M]
  [inst_3 : IsNoetherian R M] (f : M →ₗ[R] M), Function.Surjective ↑f → Function.Bijective ↑f :=

/-- Group homomorphisms preserve inverse. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} {F : Type u_3} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : DivisionMonoid H]
  [inst_2 : MonoidHomClass F G H] (f : F) (a : G), ↑f a⁻¹ = (↑f a)⁻¹ :=

/-- The induced algebra morphism from the quotient by the kernel is injective. -/
theorem ∀ {R₁ : Type u_1} {A : Type u_2} {B : Type u_3} [inst : CommSemiring R₁] [inst_1 : CommRing A] [inst_2 : CommRing B]
  [inst_3 : Algebra R₁ A] [inst_4 : Algebra R₁ B] (f : A →ₐ[R₁] B), Function.Injective ↑(Ideal.kerLiftAlg f) :=

/-- The ring homomorphism is surjective -/
theorem ∀ {R₁ : Type u_1} {R₂ : Type u_2} [inst : Semiring R₁] [inst_1 : Semiring R₂] {σ : R₁ →+* R₂}
  [self : RingHomSurjective σ], Function.Surjective ↑σ :=

/-- A monoid homomorphism `f` induces an injective homomorphism on the quotient by `f`'s kernel. -/
theorem ∀ {M : Type u_1} {P : Type u_2} [inst : MulOneClass M] [inst_1 : MulOneClass P] (f : M →* P),
  Function.Injective ↑(Con.kerLift f) :=

/-- Composing with a surjective linear map is injective. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : Semiring R] {M : Type u_3} [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid M] [inst_2 : Module R M] {N : Type u_4}
  [inst_3 : AddCommMonoid N] [inst_4 : Module R N] {ι : Type u_5} {M₂ : Type u_2} [inst_5 : AddCommMonoid M₂]
  [inst_6 : Module R M₂] (f : M₂ →ₗ[R] M),
  Function.Surjective ↑f → Function.Injective fun g => AlternatingMap.compLinearMap g f :=

/-- A group homomorphism sends inverses to inverses. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : Group α] [inst_1 : Group β] {f : α → β}, IsGroupHom f → ∀ (a : α), f a⁻¹ = (f a)⁻¹ :=

/-- A monomorphism is injective. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} {R₂ : Type u_2} {M : Type u_3} {M₂ : Type u_4} [inst : Semiring R] [inst_1 : Semiring R₂]
  [inst_2 : AddCommMonoid M] [inst_3 : AddCommMonoid M₂] [inst_4 : Module R M] [inst_5 : Module R₂ M₂] {τ₁₂ : R →+* R₂}
  {f : M →ₛₗ[τ₁₂] M₂},
  (∀ (u v : { x // x ∈ LinearMap.ker f } →ₗ[R] M), LinearMap.comp f u = LinearMap.comp f v → u = v) →
    LinearMap.ker f = ⊥ :=

/-- Composing with a family of surjective linear maps is injective. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} {ι : Type u'} {M₁ : ι → Type v₁} {M₂ : Type v₂} [inst : Semiring R]
  [inst_1 : (i : ι) → AddCommMonoid (M₁ i)] [inst_2 : AddCommMonoid M₂] [inst_3 : (i : ι) → Module R (M₁ i)]
  [inst_4 : Module R M₂] {M₁' : ι → Type u_1} [inst_5 : (i : ι) → AddCommMonoid (M₁' i)]
  [inst_6 : (i : ι) → Module R (M₁' i)] (f : (i : ι) → M₁ i →ₗ[R] M₁' i),
  (∀ (i : ι), Function.Surjective ↑(f i)) → Function.Injective fun g => MultilinearMap.compLinearMap g f :=

/-- The canonical map from the type to the free group is an injection. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u}, Function.Injective FreeGroup.of :=

/-- The natural homomorphism from a monoid to its quotient by a congruence relation is
surjective. -/
theorem ∀ {M : Type u_1} [inst : MulOneClass M] {c : Con M}, Function.Surjective ↑(Con.mk' c) :=

/-- Any continuous bijection of compact Hausdorff spaces is an isomorphism. -/
theorem ∀ {X Y : CompHaus} (f : X ⟶ Y), Function.Bijective ↑f → CategoryTheory.IsIso f :=

/-- Every surjective homomorphism from a finitely generated free group to itself is injective. -/
theorem
choices:
∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Fintype α] (f : FreeGroup α →* FreeGroup α),
  Function.Surjective ↑f → Function.Injective ↑f

prompt_cons:
/-- Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization -/
theorem Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ≠ 0} :=

/-- The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication. -/
theorem ∀ {a b x y u v : ℕ}, a = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 → b = u ^ 2 + v ^ 2 → ∃ r s, a * b = r ^ 2 + s ^ 2 :=

/-- Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, (∀ (a : ℕ), a ∣ m ↔ a ∣ n) ↔ m = n :=

/-- Two positive naturals are equal if their prime padic valuations are equal -/
theorem ∀ (a b : ℕ), a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → (a = b ↔ ∀ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p → padicValNat p a = padicValNat p b) :=

/-- Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, (∀ (a : ℕ), m ∣ a ↔ n ∣ a) ↔ m = n :=

/-- The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [dec_irr : (p : Associates α) → Decidable (Irreducible p)]
  [inst_1 : UniqueFactorizationMonoid α] [dec : DecidableEq α] [dec' : DecidableEq (Associates α)] {a p : Associates α},
  Irreducible p →
    ∀ [inst_2 : (n : ℕ) → Decidable (a ∣ p ^ n)] {n : ℕ} (h : a ∣ p ^ n),
      a = p ^ Nat.find (_ : ∃ n, (fun n => a ∣ p ^ n) n) :=

/-- If `a`, `b` are positive, the prime divisors of `a * b` are the union of those of `a` and `b` -/
theorem ∀ {a b : ℕ},
  a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → List.toFinset (Nat.factors (a * b)) = List.toFinset (Nat.factors a) ∪ List.toFinset (Nat.factors b) :=

/-- The product of two positive elements is positive. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [self : StrictOrderedRing α] (a b : α), 0 < a → 0 < b → 0 < a * b :=

/-- If a product lies in the prime ideal, then at least one element lies in the prime ideal. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Semiring α] {I : Ideal α} [self : Ideal.IsPrime I] {x y : α}, x * y ∈ I → x ∈ I ∨ y ∈ I :=

/-- The numerator and denominator are coprime: it is in "reduced form". -/
theorem ∀ (self : ℚ), Nat.coprime (Int.natAbs self.num) self.den :=

/-- There is a rational power between any two positive elements of an archimedean ordered field. -/
theorem ∀ {n : ℕ} {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α],
  n ≠ 0 → ∀ {x y : α}, x < y → 0 < y → ∃ q, 0 < q ∧ x < ↑q ^ n ∧ ↑q ^ n < y :=

/-- Any common divisor of both elements is a divisor of the GCD. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [self : GCDMonoid α] {a b c : α}, a ∣ c → a ∣ b → a ∣ gcd c b :=

/-- Every x greater than or equal to 1 is between two successive
natural-number powers of every y greater than one. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedRing α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] {x y : α},
  1 ≤ x → 1 < y → ∃ n, y ^ n ≤ x ∧ x < y ^ (n + 1) :=

/-- **Bertrand's Postulate**: For any positive natural number, there is a prime which is greater than
it, but no more than twice as large. -/
theorem ∀ (n : ℕ), n ≠ 0 → ∃ p, Nat.Prime p ∧ n < p ∧ p ≤ 2 * n :=

/-- If two integers are congruent to a sufficiently large modulus,
they are equal. -/
theorem ∀ {a b c : ℤ}, a % b = c → Int.natAbs (a - c) < Int.natAbs b → a = c :=

/-- For any positive `k : ℕ` there are infinitely many primes `p` such that `p ≡ 1 [MOD k]`. -/
theorem ∀ {k : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → Set.Infinite {p | Nat.Prime p ∧ p ≡ 1 [MOD k]} :=

/-- A finite group of prime order is simple. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Group α] [inst_1 : Fintype α] {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  Fintype.card α = p → IsSimpleGroup α :=

/-- For positive `a` and `b`, the prime factors of `a * b` are the union of those of `a` and `b` -/
theorem ∀ {a b : ℕ}, a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → Nat.factors (a * b) ~ Nat.factors a ++ Nat.factors b :=

/-- The only numbers with empty prime factorization are `0` and `1` -/
theorem ∀ (n : ℕ), Nat.factorization n = 0 ↔ n = 0 ∨ n = 1 :=

/-- The product of a list of positive natural numbers is positive,
and likewise for any nontrivial ordered semiring. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : StrictOrderedSemiring R] (l : List R), (∀ (a : R), a ∈ l → 0 < a) → 0 < List.prod l :=

/-- Every positive even integer can be written as the sum of two primes. -/
theorem
choices: ∀ (n : ℕ), n ≠ 0 → Even n → ∃ p q, Nat.Prime p ∧ Nat.Prime q ∧ n = p + q

docString: Every matrix satisfies its own characteristic polynomial.
prompts:
[{"theorem":
  "∀ {α : Type u_2} {n : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq n] [inst_1 : Zero α] [inst_2 : One α], Matrix.IsDiag 1",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "Every identity matrix is diagonal. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {σ : Type u_1} {R : Type u_2} [inst : CommSemiring R] (p : MvPolynomial σ R),\n  ∃ n f _hf q, p = ↑(MvPolynomial.rename f) q",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "Every polynomial is a polynomial in finitely many variables. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {A : Type u_1} {B : Type u_2} [inst : Field A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : IsDomain B] [inst_3 : Algebra A B] {x : B},\n  IsIntegral A x → x ≠ 0 → Polynomial.coeff (minpoly A x) 0 ≠ 0",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "The minimal polynomial of a nonzero element has nonzero constant coefficient. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {R : Type u} {M : Type v} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : Nontrivial R] [inst_2 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_3 : Module R M]\n  [inst_4 : Module.Free R M] [inst_5 : Module.Finite R M] (f : M →ₗ[R] M) {ι : Type w} [inst_6 : Fintype ι]\n  (b : Basis ι R M), Matrix.charpoly (↑(LinearMap.toMatrix b b) f) = LinearMap.charpoly f",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "`charpoly f` is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix of `f` in any basis. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] {n : Type v} [inst_1 : DecidableEq n] [inst_2 : Fintype n] (M : Matrix n n R)\n  (p : Polynomial R), ↑(Polynomial.aeval M) p = ↑(Polynomial.aeval M) (p %ₘ Matrix.charpoly M)",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "Any matrix polynomial `p` is equivalent under evaluation to `p %ₘ M.charpoly`; that is, `p`\nis equivalent to a polynomial with degree less than the dimension of the matrix. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {R : Type u_1} {M : Type u_3} [inst : CommSemiring R] {σ : Type u_2} [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid M] (w : σ → M)\n  (φ : MvPolynomial σ R), ∑ᶠ (m : M), ↑(MvPolynomial.weightedHomogeneousComponent w m) φ = φ",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "Every polynomial is the sum of its weighted homogeneous components. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommSemiring R] (I : Ideal (Polynomial R)) (p : Polynomial R),\n  (∀ (n : ℕ), Polynomial.coeff p n ∈ Ideal.comap Polynomial.C I) → p ∈ I",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "If every coefficient of a polynomial is in an ideal `I`, then so is the polynomial itself "},
 {"theorem": "∀ {α : Type u_1} {n : Type u_2} [inst : Zero α], Matrix.IsDiag 0",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "Every zero matrix is diagonal. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {A : Type u_1} {B : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : Algebra A B] {x : B},\n  IsIntegral A x → Polynomial.Monic (minpoly A x)",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "A minimal polynomial is monic. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {A : Type u_1} {B : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : Algebra A B] {x : B}\n  [inst_3 : IsDomain A] [inst_4 : IsDomain B], IsIntegral A x → Irreducible (minpoly A x)",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "A minimal polynomial is irreducible. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {A : Type u_2} {B : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : Algebra A B] {x : B}\n  [inst_3 : Nontrivial B], IsIntegral A x → 0 < Polynomial.degree (minpoly A x)",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "The degree of a minimal polynomial is positive. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {A : Type u_1} {B : Type u_2} [inst : Field A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : IsDomain B] [inst_3 : Algebra A B] {x : B},\n  IsIntegral A x → Prime (minpoly A x)",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "A minimal polynomial is prime. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {R : Type u} {σ : Type v} [inst : CommRing R] (I : Ideal (MvPolynomial σ R)) (p : MvPolynomial σ R),\n  (∀ (m : σ →₀ ℕ), MvPolynomial.coeff m p ∈ Ideal.comap MvPolynomial.C I) → p ∈ I",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "If every coefficient of a polynomial is in an ideal `I`, then so is the polynomial itself,\nmultivariate version. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {n : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq n] [inst_1 : Fintype n] {R : Type v} [inst_2 : CommRing R] {M : Matrix n n R}\n  {i j : n}, i ≠ j → (∀ (k : n), M k i = M k j) → Matrix.det M = 0",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "If a matrix has a repeated column, the determinant will be zero. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {n : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq n] [inst_1 : Fintype n] {R : Type v} [inst_2 : CommRing R] (σ : Equiv.Perm n),\n  Matrix.det (PEquiv.toMatrix (Equiv.toPEquiv σ)) = ↑↑(↑Equiv.Perm.sign σ)",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "The determinant of a permutation matrix equals its sign. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {n : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq n] [inst_1 : Fintype n] {R : Type v} [inst_2 : CommRing R] {M : Matrix n n R}\n  {i j : n}, i ≠ j → M i = M j → Matrix.det M = 0",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "If a matrix has a repeated row, the determinant will be zero. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {n : Type u'} {α : Type v} [inst : Fintype n] [inst_1 : DecidableEq n] [inst_2 : CommRing α] {A B C : Matrix n n α},\n  Matrix.mul A B = 1 → Matrix.mul A C = 1 → B = C",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "The right inverse of matrix A is unique when existing. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] {n : Type w} [inst_1 : DecidableEq n] [inst_2 : Fintype n] (M : Matrix n n R),\n  ↑(Polynomial.aeval M) (Matrix.charpoly M) = 0",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "The **Cayley-Hamilton Theorem**, that the characteristic polynomial of a matrix,\napplied to the matrix itself, is zero.\n\nThis holds over any commutative ring.\n\nSee `LinearMap.aeval_self_charpoly` for the equivalent statement about endomorphisms.\n"},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ (R : Type u_1) [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : Algebra ℚ R] (I : Ideal R), I ≠ ⊤ → CharZero (R ⧸ I)",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString": "`ℚ`-algebra implies equal characteristic. "},
 {"theorem":
  "∀ (R : Type w₁) [inst : CommRing R] (ι : Type u_2) [inst_1 : Finite ι], Algebra.FinitePresentation R (MvPolynomial ι R)",
  "isProp": true,
  "docString":
  "The ring of polynomials in finitely many variables is finitely presented. "}]
prompt_cons:
/-- Every identity matrix is diagonal. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_2} {n : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq n] [inst_1 : Zero α] [inst_2 : One α], Matrix.IsDiag 1 :=

/-- Every polynomial is a polynomial in finitely many variables. -/
theorem ∀ {σ : Type u_1} {R : Type u_2} [inst : CommSemiring R] (p : MvPolynomial σ R),
  ∃ n f _hf q, p = ↑(MvPolynomial.rename f) q :=

/-- The minimal polynomial of a nonzero element has nonzero constant coefficient. -/
theorem ∀ {A : Type u_1} {B : Type u_2} [inst : Field A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : IsDomain B] [inst_3 : Algebra A B] {x : B},
  IsIntegral A x → x ≠ 0 → Polynomial.coeff (minpoly A x) 0 ≠ 0 :=

/-- `charpoly f` is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix of `f` in any basis. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} {M : Type v} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : Nontrivial R] [inst_2 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_3 : Module R M]
  [inst_4 : Module.Free R M] [inst_5 : Module.Finite R M] (f : M →ₗ[R] M) {ι : Type w} [inst_6 : Fintype ι]
  (b : Basis ι R M), Matrix.charpoly (↑(LinearMap.toMatrix b b) f) = LinearMap.charpoly f :=

/-- Any matrix polynomial `p` is equivalent under evaluation to `p %ₘ M.charpoly`; that is, `p`
is equivalent to a polynomial with degree less than the dimension of the matrix. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] {n : Type v} [inst_1 : DecidableEq n] [inst_2 : Fintype n] (M : Matrix n n R)
  (p : Polynomial R), ↑(Polynomial.aeval M) p = ↑(Polynomial.aeval M) (p %ₘ Matrix.charpoly M) :=

/-- Every polynomial is the sum of its weighted homogeneous components. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} {M : Type u_3} [inst : CommSemiring R] {σ : Type u_2} [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid M] (w : σ → M)
  (φ : MvPolynomial σ R), ∑ᶠ (m : M), ↑(MvPolynomial.weightedHomogeneousComponent w m) φ = φ :=

/-- If every coefficient of a polynomial is in an ideal `I`, then so is the polynomial itself -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommSemiring R] (I : Ideal (Polynomial R)) (p : Polynomial R),
  (∀ (n : ℕ), Polynomial.coeff p n ∈ Ideal.comap Polynomial.C I) → p ∈ I :=

/-- Every zero matrix is diagonal. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} {n : Type u_2} [inst : Zero α], Matrix.IsDiag 0 :=

/-- A minimal polynomial is monic. -/
theorem ∀ {A : Type u_1} {B : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : Algebra A B] {x : B},
  IsIntegral A x → Polynomial.Monic (minpoly A x) :=

/-- A minimal polynomial is irreducible. -/
theorem ∀ {A : Type u_1} {B : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : Algebra A B] {x : B}
  [inst_3 : IsDomain A] [inst_4 : IsDomain B], IsIntegral A x → Irreducible (minpoly A x) :=

/-- The degree of a minimal polynomial is positive. -/
theorem ∀ {A : Type u_2} {B : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : Algebra A B] {x : B}
  [inst_3 : Nontrivial B], IsIntegral A x → 0 < Polynomial.degree (minpoly A x) :=

/-- A minimal polynomial is prime. -/
theorem ∀ {A : Type u_1} {B : Type u_2} [inst : Field A] [inst_1 : Ring B] [inst_2 : IsDomain B] [inst_3 : Algebra A B] {x : B},
  IsIntegral A x → Prime (minpoly A x) :=

/-- If every coefficient of a polynomial is in an ideal `I`, then so is the polynomial itself,
multivariate version. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} {σ : Type v} [inst : CommRing R] (I : Ideal (MvPolynomial σ R)) (p : MvPolynomial σ R),
  (∀ (m : σ →₀ ℕ), MvPolynomial.coeff m p ∈ Ideal.comap MvPolynomial.C I) → p ∈ I :=

/-- If a matrix has a repeated column, the determinant will be zero. -/
theorem ∀ {n : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq n] [inst_1 : Fintype n] {R : Type v} [inst_2 : CommRing R] {M : Matrix n n R}
  {i j : n}, i ≠ j → (∀ (k : n), M k i = M k j) → Matrix.det M = 0 :=

/-- The determinant of a permutation matrix equals its sign. -/
theorem ∀ {n : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq n] [inst_1 : Fintype n] {R : Type v} [inst_2 : CommRing R] (σ : Equiv.Perm n),
  Matrix.det (PEquiv.toMatrix (Equiv.toPEquiv σ)) = ↑↑(↑Equiv.Perm.sign σ) :=

/-- If a matrix has a repeated row, the determinant will be zero. -/
theorem ∀ {n : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq n] [inst_1 : Fintype n] {R : Type v} [inst_2 : CommRing R] {M : Matrix n n R}
  {i j : n}, i ≠ j → M i = M j → Matrix.det M = 0 :=

/-- The right inverse of matrix A is unique when existing. -/
theorem ∀ {n : Type u'} {α : Type v} [inst : Fintype n] [inst_1 : DecidableEq n] [inst_2 : CommRing α] {A B C : Matrix n n α},
  Matrix.mul A B = 1 → Matrix.mul A C = 1 → B = C :=

/-- The **Cayley-Hamilton Theorem**, that the characteristic polynomial of a matrix,
applied to the matrix itself, is zero.

This holds over any commutative ring.

See `LinearMap.aeval_self_charpoly` for the equivalent statement about endomorphisms. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] {n : Type w} [inst_1 : DecidableEq n] [inst_2 : Fintype n] (M : Matrix n n R),
  ↑(Polynomial.aeval M) (Matrix.charpoly M) = 0 :=

/-- `ℚ`-algebra implies equal characteristic. -/
theorem ∀ (R : Type u_1) [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : Algebra ℚ R] (I : Ideal R), I ≠ ⊤ → CharZero (R ⧸ I) :=

/-- The ring of polynomials in finitely many variables is finitely presented. -/
theorem ∀ (R : Type w₁) [inst : CommRing R] (ι : Type u_2) [inst_1 : Finite ι], Algebra.FinitePresentation R (MvPolynomial ι R) :=

/-- Every matrix satisfies its own characteristic polynomial. -/
theorem
choices:
∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] {n : Type w} [inst_1 : DecidableEq n] [inst_2 : Fintype n] (M : Matrix n n R),
  Polynomial.aeval M (Matrix.charpoly M) = 0

/-- A transcendental real number is irrational. -/
theorem ∀ {r : ℝ}, Transcendental ℚ r → Irrational r :=

/-- The conjugate of the golden ratio is irrational. -/
theorem Irrational goldenConj :=

/-- **Irrationality of the Square Root of 2** -/
theorem Irrational (Real.sqrt 2) :=

/-- The golden ratio is irrational. -/
theorem Irrational goldenRatio :=

theorem ∀ {a : ℕ}, ↑(Nat.sqrt a) ≤ Real.sqrt ↑a :=

/-- The real square root is at most the natural square root plus one -/
theorem ∀ {a : ℕ}, Real.sqrt ↑a ≤ ↑(Nat.sqrt a) + 1 :=

/-- A number satisfying the Liouville condition with exponent `p > 1` is an irrational number. -/
theorem ∀ {p x : ℝ}, LiouvilleWith p x → 1 < p → Irrational x :=

/-- There is an irrational number `r` between any two reals `x < r < y`. -/
theorem ∀ {x y : ℝ}, x < y → ∃ r, Irrational r ∧ x < r ∧ r < y :=

/-- The continued fraction of a rational number terminates. -/
theorem ∀ (q : ℚ), GeneralizedContinuedFraction.Terminates (GeneralizedContinuedFraction.of q) :=

/-- If `x + y` is irrational, then at least one of `x` and `y` is irrational. -/
theorem ∀ {x y : ℝ}, Irrational (x + y) → Irrational x ∨ Irrational y :=

/-- Every finite convergent corresponds to a rational number. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField K] [inst_1 : FloorRing K] (v : K) (n : ℕ),
  ∃ q, GeneralizedContinuedFraction.convergents (GeneralizedContinuedFraction.of v) n = ↑q :=

/-- A rational number has only finitely many good rational approximations. -/
theorem ∀ (ξ : ℚ), Set.Finite {q | |ξ - q| < 1 / ↑q.den ^ 2} :=

/-- A quadratic has no root if its discriminant has no square root. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] {a b c : R},
  (∀ (s : R), discrim a b c ≠ s ^ 2) → ∀ (x : R), a * x * x + b * x + c ≠ 0 :=

theorem ¬Set.Countable Set.univ :=

/-- If `x^n`, `n > 0`, is integer and is not the `n`-th power of an integer, then
`x` is irrational. -/
theorem ∀ {x : ℝ} (n : ℕ) (m : ℤ), x ^ n = ↑m → (¬∃ y, x = ↑y) → 0 < n → Irrational x :=

/-- Every terminating continued fraction corresponds to a rational number. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField K] [inst_1 : FloorRing K] {v : K},
  GeneralizedContinuedFraction.Terminates (GeneralizedContinuedFraction.of v) → ∃ q, v = ↑q :=

theorem ∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField 𝕜] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace 𝕜] [inst_2 : OrderTopology 𝕜]
  [inst_3 : Archimedean 𝕜], DenseRange Rat.cast :=

theorem ∀ (K : Type u_1) [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : NumberField K] (A : Type u_2) [inst_2 : NormedField A]
  [inst_3 : IsAlgClosed A] [inst_4 : NormedAlgebra ℚ A] {x : K},
  IsIntegral ℤ x → (∀ (φ : K →+* A), ‖↑φ x‖ = 1) → ∃ n x_1, x ^ n = 1 :=

/-- The set of good rational approximations to a real number `ξ` is infinite if and only if
`ξ` is irrational. -/
theorem ∀ (ξ : ℝ), Set.Infinite {q | |ξ - ↑q| < 1 / ↑q.den ^ 2} ↔ Irrational ξ :=

/-- An ideal is radical iff it is equal to its radical. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommSemiring R] {I : Ideal R}, Ideal.radical I = I ↔ Ideal.IsRadical I :=

/-- The square root of an irrational number is irrational. -/
theorem

/-- The sum of two squares is zero iff both elements are zero. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : LinearOrderedRing α] {x y : α}, x * x + y * y = 0 ↔ x = 0 ∧ y = 0 :=

/-- The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication. -/
theorem ∀ {a b x y u v : ℕ}, a = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 → b = u ^ 2 + v ^ 2 → ∃ r s, a * b = r ^ 2 + s ^ 2 :=

/-- The convolution of two even functions is also even. -/
theorem ∀ {𝕜 : Type u𝕜} {G : Type uG} {E : Type uE} {E' : Type uE'} {F : Type uF} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E'] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] {f : G → E} {g : G → E'} {x : G}
  [inst_3 : NontriviallyNormedField 𝕜] [inst_4 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E] [inst_5 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E'] [inst_6 : NormedSpace 𝕜 F]
  (L : E →L[𝕜] E' →L[𝕜] F) [inst_7 : MeasurableSpace G] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure G} [inst_8 : NormedSpace ℝ F]
  [inst_9 : AddCommGroup G] [inst_10 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsAddLeftInvariant μ]
  [inst_11 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsNegInvariant μ] [inst_12 : MeasurableNeg G] [inst_13 : MeasurableAdd G],
  (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, f (-x) = f x) → (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, g (-x) = g x) → convolution f g L (-x) = convolution f g L x :=

/-- Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, (∀ (a : ℕ), m ∣ a ↔ n ∣ a) ↔ m = n :=

/-- In a finite field of characteristic `2`, all elements are squares. -/
theorem ∀ {F : Type u_1} [inst : Field F] [inst_1 : Finite F], ringChar F = 2 → ∀ (a : F), IsSquare a :=

/-- **Euler's four-square identity**, a version for natural numbers. -/
theorem ∀ (a b c d x y z w : ℕ),
  Int.natAbs (↑a * ↑x - ↑b * ↑y - ↑c * ↑z - ↑d * ↑w) ^ 2 + Int.natAbs (↑a * ↑y + ↑b * ↑x + ↑c * ↑w - ↑d * ↑z) ^ 2 +
        Int.natAbs (↑a * ↑z - ↑b * ↑w + ↑c * ↑x + ↑d * ↑y) ^ 2 +
      Int.natAbs (↑a * ↑w + ↑b * ↑z - ↑c * ↑y + ↑d * ↑x) ^ 2 =
    (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 + d ^ 2) * (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 + w ^ 2) :=

/-- If `-1` is a square modulo the natural number `n`, then `n` is a sum of two squares. -/
theorem ∀ {n : ℕ}, IsSquare (-1) → ∃ x y, n = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 :=

/-- The square of the quadratic character on nonzero arguments is `1`. -/
theorem ∀ {F : Type u_1} [inst : Field F] [inst_1 : Fintype F] [inst_2 : DecidableEq F] {a : F},
  a ≠ 0 → ↑(quadraticChar F) a ^ 2 = 1 :=

/-- Commutativity of a square is preserved when taking quotients by an ideal. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} {S : Type v} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : CommRing S] {R' : Type u_1} {S' : Type u_2}
  [inst_2 : CommRing R'] [inst_3 : CommRing S'] {f : R →+* S} {f' : R' →+* S'} {g : R →+* R'} {g' : S →+* S'}
  (hfg : RingHom.comp f' g = RingHom.comp g' f) (I : Ideal S'),
  let leq := (_ : Ideal.comap f (Ideal.comap g' I) ≤ Ideal.comap g (Ideal.comap f' I));
  RingHom.comp (Ideal.quotientMap I g' (_ : Ideal.comap g' I ≤ Ideal.comap g' I))
      (Ideal.quotientMap (Ideal.comap g' I) f
        (_ : Ideal.comap f (Ideal.comap g' I) ≤ Ideal.comap f (Ideal.comap g' I))) =
    RingHom.comp (Ideal.quotientMap I f' (_ : Ideal.comap f' I ≤ Ideal.comap f' I))
      (Ideal.quotientMap (Ideal.comap f' I) g leq) :=

/-- The `n`th power of a quadratic character is itself, when `n` is odd. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] {R' : Type v} [inst_1 : CommRing R'] {χ : MulChar R R'},
  MulChar.IsQuadratic χ → ∀ {n : ℕ}, Odd n → χ ^ n = χ :=

/-- Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, (∀ (a : ℕ), a ∣ m ↔ a ∣ n) ↔ m = n :=

/-- The sum over the values of the quadratic character is zero when the characteristic is odd. -/
theorem ∀ {F : Type u_1} [inst : Field F] [inst_1 : Fintype F] [inst_2 : DecidableEq F],
  ringChar F ≠ 2 → (Finset.sum Finset.univ fun a => ↑(quadraticChar F) a) = 0 :=

/-- The square of a quadratic character is the trivial character. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] {R' : Type v} [inst_1 : CommRing R'] {χ : MulChar R R'},
  MulChar.IsQuadratic χ → χ ^ 2 = 1 :=

/-- The square of `J(a | b)` is `1` when `a` and `b` are coprime. -/
theorem ∀ {a : ℤ} {b : ℕ}, Int.gcd a ↑b = 1 → jacobiSym a b ^ 2 = 1 :=

/-- A square has a lifting if and only if its (right) adjoint square has a lifting. -/
theorem ∀ {C : Type u_1} {D : Type u_4} [inst : CategoryTheory.Category C] [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Category D]
  {G : CategoryTheory.Functor C D} {F : CategoryTheory.Functor D C} {A B : C} {X Y : D} {i : A ⟶ B} {p : X ⟶ Y}
  {u : G.obj A ⟶ X} {v : G.obj B ⟶ Y} (sq : CategoryTheory.CommSq u (G.map i) p v) (adj : G ⊣ F),
  CategoryTheory.CommSq.HasLift
      (_ :
        CategoryTheory.CommSq (↑(CategoryTheory.Adjunction.homEquiv adj A X) u) i (F.map p)
          (↑(CategoryTheory.Adjunction.homEquiv adj B Y) v)) ↔
    CategoryTheory.CommSq.HasLift sq :=

/-- **Euler's four-square identity**. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] (a b c d x y z w : R),
  (a * x - b * y - c * z - d * w) ^ 2 + (a * y + b * x + c * w - d * z) ^ 2 + (a * z - b * w + c * x + d * y) ^ 2 +
      (a * w + b * z - c * y + d * x) ^ 2 =
    (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 + d ^ 2) * (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 + w ^ 2) :=

/-- The square of the symbol is 1 if `p ∤ a`. -/
theorem ∀ (p : ℕ) [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] {a : ℤ}, ↑a ≠ 0 → legendreSym p a ^ 2 = 1 :=

/-- **Four squares theorem** -/
theorem ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ a b c d, a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 + d ^ 2 = n :=

/-- `2` is a square in `F` iff `#F` is not congruent to `3` or `5` mod `8`. -/
theorem ∀ {F : Type u_1} [inst : Field F] [inst_1 : Fintype F], IsSquare 2 ↔ Fintype.card F % 8 ≠ 3 ∧ Fintype.card F % 8 ≠ 5 :=

/-- `2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `7` mod `8`. -/
theorem ∀ {p : ℕ} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p ≠ 2 → (IsSquare 2 ↔ p % 8 = 1 ∨ p % 8 = 7) :=

/-- If the square of a number is even, the number itself is even. -/
theorem

/-- If all prime ideals in a commutative ring are principal, so are all other ideals. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R],
  (∀ (P : Ideal R), Ideal.IsPrime P → Submodule.IsPrincipal P) → IsPrincipalIdealRing R :=

/-- If the quotient by an ideal is a field, then the ideal is maximal. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] (I : Ideal R), IsField (R ⧸ I) → Ideal.IsMaximal I :=

/-- The quotient of a ring by an ideal is a field iff the ideal is maximal. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] (I : Ideal R), Ideal.IsMaximal I ↔ IsField (R ⧸ I) :=

/-- Maximal ideals in complete normed rings are closed. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : NormedRing R] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace R] {I : Ideal R} [hI : Ideal.IsMaximal I], IsClosed ↑I :=

/-- An invertible ideal in a commutative ring with finitely many maximal ideals is principal.

https://math.stackexchange.com/a/95857 -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R],
  Set.Finite {I | Ideal.IsMaximal I} → ∀ {I : Ideal R}, IsUnit ↑I → Submodule.IsPrincipal I :=

/-- Krull's theorem: a nontrivial ring has a maximal ideal. -/
theorem ∀ (α : Type u) [inst : Semiring α] [inst_1 : Nontrivial α], ∃ M, Ideal.IsMaximal M :=

/-- Any finitely generated ideal is principal. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] [self : IsBezout R] (I : Ideal R), Ideal.FG I → Submodule.IsPrincipal I :=

/-- An invertible fractional ideal of a commutative ring with finitely many maximal ideals is principal.

https://math.stackexchange.com/a/95857 -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] {A : Type u_1} [inst_1 : CommRing A] [inst_2 : Algebra R A] {S : Submonoid R}
  [inst_3 : IsLocalization S A],
  S ≤ nonZeroDivisors R →
    Set.Finite {I | Ideal.IsMaximal I} → ∀ (I I' : FractionalIdeal S A), I * I' = 1 → Submodule.IsPrincipal ↑I :=

/-- The maximal ideal is a coatom in the ordering on ideals; that is, it is not the entire ring,
and there are no other proper ideals strictly containing it. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Semiring α] {I : Ideal α} [self : Ideal.IsMaximal I], IsCoatom I :=

/-- A ring is Noetherian if and only if all its ideals are finitely-generated. -/
theorem ∀ (R : Type u_1) [inst : Semiring R], IsNoetherianRing R ↔ ∀ (I : Ideal R), Ideal.FG I :=

/-- The prime divisors of the characteristic of a finite commutative ring are exactly
the prime divisors of its cardinality. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : Fintype R] (p : ℕ) [inst_2 : Fact (Nat.Prime p)],
  p ∣ ringChar R ↔ p ∣ Fintype.card R :=

/-- When a ring is not a field, the maximal ideals are nontrivial. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommSemiring R] [inst_1 : Nontrivial R] {M : Ideal R}, Ideal.IsMaximal M → ¬IsField R → M ≠ ⊥ :=

/-- The category of commutative rings has all limits. -/
theorem CategoryTheory.Limits.HasLimitsOfSize.{v, v, max u v, max (u + 1) (v + 1)} CommRingCatMax :=

/-- This ideal is maximal in the collection of proper ideals. -/
theorem ∀ {P : Type u_1} [inst : LE P] {I : Order.Ideal P} [self : Order.Ideal.IsMaximal I] ⦃J : Order.Ideal P⦄,
  I < J → ↑J = Set.univ :=

theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} {K : Type u_2} {F : Type u_3} [inst : Ring R] [inst_1 : Field K] [inst_2 : RingHomClass F R K] (f : F),
  Function.Surjective ↑f → Ideal.IsMaximal (RingHom.ker f) :=

theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : NormedRing R] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace R] {I : Ideal R}, Ideal.IsMaximal I → Ideal.closure I = I :=

/-- The variable of the power series ring over an integral domain is prime. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R], Prime PowerSeries.X :=

/-- The prime spectrum of a commutative ring is a compact topological space. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R], CompactSpace (PrimeSpectrum R) :=

/-- The only constant in a maximal ideal over a field is `0`. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : Ring R],
  IsField R → ∀ (I : Ideal (Polynomial R)) [hI : Ideal.IsMaximal I] (x : R), ↑Polynomial.C x ∈ I → x = 0 :=

/-- The unique maximal ideal of the localization at `I.prime_compl` lies over the ideal `I`. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommSemiring R] {I : Ideal R} [hI : Ideal.IsPrime I],
  Ideal.comap (algebraMap R (Localization.AtPrime I)) (LocalRing.maximalIdeal (Localization (Ideal.primeCompl I))) = I :=

/-- A continuous map from a compact space to a Hausdorff space is a closed map. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_2 : CompactSpace α]
  [inst_3 : T2Space β] {f : α → β}, Continuous f → IsClosedMap f :=

/-- The **Heine–Borel theorem**:
In a proper Hausdorff space, a set is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace α] {s : Set α} [inst_1 : T2Space α] [inst_2 : ProperSpace α],
  IsCompact s ↔ IsClosed s ∧ Metric.Bounded s :=

/-- Every two points in a Hausdorff space admit disjoint open neighbourhoods. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [self : T2Space α] (x y : α),
  x ≠ y → ∃ u v, IsOpen u ∧ IsOpen v ∧ x ∈ u ∧ y ∈ v ∧ Disjoint u v :=

/-- In a complete space, the type of closed subsets is complete for the
Hausdorff edistance. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : EMetricSpace α] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace α], CompleteSpace (TopologicalSpace.Closeds α) :=

/-- Two closed sets are at zero Hausdorff distance if and only if they coincide -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace α] {s t : Set α},
  IsClosed s → IsClosed t → EMetric.hausdorffEdist s t ≠ ⊤ → (Metric.hausdorffDist s t = 0 ↔ s = t) :=

/-- A locally compact Hausdorff space is totally disconnected
if and only if it is totally separated. -/
theorem ∀ {H : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace H] [inst_1 : LocallyCompactSpace H] [inst_2 : T2Space H],
  TotallyDisconnectedSpace H ↔ TotallySeparatedSpace H :=

/-- A locally compact Hausdorff totally disconnected space has a basis with clopen elements. -/
theorem ∀ {H : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace H] [inst_1 : LocallyCompactSpace H] [inst_2 : T2Space H]
  [inst_3 : TotallyDisconnectedSpace H], TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis {s | IsClopen s} :=

/-- Any continuous function on compact Hausdorff spaces is a closed map. -/
theorem ∀ {X Y : CompHaus} (f : X ⟶ Y), IsClosedMap ↑f :=

/-- Two closed sets are at zero Hausdorff edistance if and only if they coincide -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : PseudoEMetricSpace α] {s t : Set α},
  IsClosed s → IsClosed t → (EMetric.hausdorffEdist s t = 0 ↔ s = t) :=

/-- The one point compactification of a locally compact Hausdorff space is a normal (hence,
Hausdorff and regular) topological space. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : LocallyCompactSpace X] [inst_2 : T2Space X],
  NormalSpace (OnePoint X) :=

/-- A compact Hausdorff space is totally disconnected if and only if it is totally separated, this
is also true for locally compact spaces. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : T2Space α] [inst_2 : CompactSpace α],
  TotallyDisconnectedSpace α ↔ TotallySeparatedSpace α :=

/-- A continuous surjective map from a compact space to a Hausdorff space is a quotient map. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_2 : CompactSpace α]
  [inst_3 : T2Space β] {f : α → β}, Function.Surjective f → Continuous f → QuotientMap f :=

/-- The Gromov-Hausdorff distance between two spaces is bounded by the Hausdorff distance
of isometric copies of the spaces, in any metric space. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type u} [inst : MetricSpace X] [inst_1 : CompactSpace X] [inst_2 : Nonempty X] {Y : Type v}
  [inst_3 : MetricSpace Y] [inst_4 : CompactSpace Y] [inst_5 : Nonempty Y] {γ : Type w} [inst_6 : MetricSpace γ]
  {Φ : X → γ} {Ψ : Y → γ},
  Isometry Φ → Isometry Ψ → GromovHausdorff.ghDist X Y ≤ Metric.hausdorffDist (Set.range Φ) (Set.range Ψ) :=

/-- If every points of a Hausdorff space admits a compact neighborhood, then this space is locally
compact. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : T2Space α],
  (∀ (x : α), ∃ s, s ∈ nhds x ∧ IsCompact s) → LocallyCompactSpace α :=

/-- Every member of an open set in a compact Hausdorff totally disconnected space
is contained in a clopen set contained in the open set. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : T2Space α] [inst_2 : CompactSpace α]
  [inst_3 : TotallyDisconnectedSpace α] {x : α} {U : Set α}, IsOpen U → x ∈ U → ∃ V, IsClopen V ∧ x ∈ V ∧ V ⊆ U :=

/-- A continuous injective map from a compact space to a Hausdorff space is a closed embedding. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_2 : CompactSpace α]
  [inst_3 : T2Space β] {f : α → β}, Continuous f → Function.Injective f → ClosedEmbedding f :=

/-- For any topological space `X`, its one point compactification is a compact space. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X], CompactSpace (OnePoint X) :=

/-- The Hausdorff distance between two sets and their closures coincide -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace α] {s t : Set α},
  Metric.hausdorffDist (closure s) (closure t) = Metric.hausdorffDist s t :=

/-- A linear order with order topology is a completely normal Hausdorff topological space. -/
theorem ∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrder X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst : OrderTopology X], T5Space X :=

/-- Any continuous bijection of compact Hausdorff spaces is an isomorphism. -/
theorem ∀ {X Y : CompHaus} (f : X ⟶ Y), Function.Bijective ↑f → CategoryTheory.IsIso f :=

/-- A topological space $X$ is Hausdorff if and only if the diagonal is a closed set in $X × X$. -/
theorem
choices: ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α], T2Space α ↔ IsClosed (Set.Diagonal α)

/-- If `a`, `b` are positive, the prime divisors of `a * b` are the union of those of `a` and `b` -/
theorem ∀ {a b : ℕ},
  a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → List.toFinset (Nat.factors (a * b)) = List.toFinset (Nat.factors a) ∪ List.toFinset (Nat.factors b) :=

/-- For positive `a` and `b`, the prime factors of `a * b` are the union of those of `a` and `b` -/
theorem ∀ {a b : ℕ}, a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → Nat.factors (a * b) ~ Nat.factors a ++ Nat.factors b :=

/-- For any two elements `x`, `y` such that `0 < y`, there exists a natural number `n`
such that `x ≤ n • y`. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : OrderedAddCommMonoid α] [self : Archimedean α] (x : α) {y : α}, 0 < y → ∃ n, x ≤ n • y :=

/-- Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, (∀ (a : ℕ), m ∣ a ↔ n ∣ a) ↔ m = n :=

/-- Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization -/
theorem Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ≠ 0} :=

/-- For coprime `a` and `b`, the prime factors of `a * b` are the union of those of `a` and `b` -/
theorem ∀ {a b : ℕ}, Nat.coprime a b → Nat.factors (a * b) ~ Nat.factors a ++ Nat.factors b :=

/-- For coprime `a` and `b` the prime factorization `a * b` is the union of those of `a` and `b` -/
theorem ∀ {a b : ℕ},
  Nat.coprime a b → (Nat.factorization (a * b)).support = (Nat.factorization a).support ∪ (Nat.factorization b).support :=

/-- If `p` is a prime factor of `b` then `p` is also a prime factor of `a * b` for any `a > 0` -/
theorem ∀ {p a b : ℕ}, p ∈ Nat.factors b → a ≠ 0 → p ∈ Nat.factors (a * b) :=

/-- Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors. -/
theorem ∀ {m n : ℕ}, (∀ (a : ℕ), a ∣ m ↔ a ∣ n) ↔ m = n :=

/-- For `a ≤ b`, there is a `c` so `b = a * c`. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [self : CanonicallyOrderedMonoid α] {a b : α}, a ≤ b → ∃ c, b = a * c :=

/-- There is a rational power between any two positive elements of an archimedean ordered field. -/
theorem ∀ {n : ℕ} {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α],
  n ≠ 0 → ∀ {x y : α}, x < y → 0 < y → ∃ q, 0 < q ∧ x < ↑q ^ n ∧ ↑q ^ n < y :=

/-- If two integers are congruent to a sufficiently large modulus,
they are equal. -/
theorem ∀ {a b c : ℤ}, a % b = c → Int.natAbs (a - c) < Int.natAbs b → a = c :=

/-- If `p` is a prime factor of `a` then `p` is also a prime factor of `a * b` for any `b > 0` -/
theorem ∀ {p a b : ℕ}, p ∈ Nat.factors a → b ≠ 0 → p ∈ Nat.factors (a * b) :=

/-- Rational numbers are dense in a linear ordered archimedean field. -/
theorem ∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedField 𝕜] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace 𝕜] [inst_2 : OrderTopology 𝕜]
  [inst_3 : Archimedean 𝕜], DenseRange Rat.cast :=

/-- The product of a list of positive natural numbers is positive,
and likewise for any nontrivial ordered semiring. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : StrictOrderedSemiring R] (l : List R), (∀ (a : R), a ∈ l → 0 < a) → 0 < List.prod l :=

/-- The prime factorizations of coprime `a` and `b` are disjoint -/
theorem ∀ {a b : ℕ}, Nat.coprime a b → Disjoint (Nat.factorization a).support (Nat.factorization b).support :=

/-- Infinitely many natural numbers are equal to `d` mod `n`. -/
theorem ∀ {n : ℕ}, n ≠ 0 → ∀ (d : ℕ), ∃ᶠ (m : ℕ) in Filter.atTop, m ≡ d [MOD n] :=

/-- For any two relatively prime positive integers $a$ and $b$, every sufficiently large natural number $N$ can be written as a linear combination $ax + by$ of $a$ and $b$, where both $x$ and $y$ are natural numbers. -/
theorem
choices: ∀ {a b : ℕ}, Nat.coprime a b → ∀ N, ∃ x y : ℕ, N ≤ a * x + b * y

/-- A field is a valuation ring. -/
theorem ∀ (K : Type u) [inst : Field K], ValuationRing K :=

  0 ∈ S :=

/-- An intermediate field contains the ring's 1. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u_2} {L : Type u_1} [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : Field L] [inst_2 : Algebra K L] (S : IntermediateField K L),
  1 ∈ S :=

/-- A linear ordered field that is a floor ring is archimedean. -/
theorem ∀ (α : Type u_1) [inst : LinearOrderedField α] [inst_1 : FloorRing α], Archimedean α :=

/-- Fields are commutative. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : Semiring R], IsField R → ∀ (x y : R), x * y = y * x :=

/-- The category of rings has all limits. -/
theorem CategoryTheory.Limits.HasLimitsOfSize.{v, v, max u v, max (u + 1) (v + 1)} CommSemiRingCatMax :=

/-- All ideals in a division (semi)ring are trivial. -/
theorem ∀ {K : Type u} [inst : DivisionSemiring K] (I : Ideal K), I = ⊥ ∨ I = ⊤ :=

/-- For a semiring to be a field, it must have two distinct elements. -/

/-- The ring of integers of a number field is not a field. -/
theorem ∀ (K : Type u_1) [inst : Field K] [nf : NumberField K], ¬IsField { x // x ∈ NumberField.ringOfIntegers K } :=

  LocalRing ↑(TopCat.Presheaf.stalk self.presheaf x) :=

theorem ∀ {F : Type u_1} {R : outParam (Type u_2)} [inst : Semiring R] [self : RingInvoClass F R] (f : F) (x : R),

theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] (I : Ideal R), Ideal.IsMaximal I ↔ IsField (R ⧸ I) :=

theorem ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : Ring R] (s : Subring R), 1 ∈ s :=

/-- Any conditionally complete linearly ordered field is archimedean. -/
theorem ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrderedField α], Archimedean α :=

theorem ∀ (R : Type u_1) [inst : NonAssocRing R] (p : ℕ) [inst : CharP R p] [inst : Finite R], p ≠ 0 :=

/-- Direct products of torsion free groups are torsion free. -/
theorem ∀ {η : Type u_1} {Gs : η → Type u_2} [inst : (i : η) → Group (Gs i)],
  (∀ (i : η), Monoid.IsTorsionFree (Gs i)) → Monoid.IsTorsionFree ((i : η) → Gs i) :=

/-- Direct products of additive torsion free groups are torsion free. -/
theorem ∀ {η : Type u_1} {Gs : η → Type u_2} [inst : (i : η) → AddGroup (Gs i)],
  (∀ (i : η), AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree (Gs i)) → AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree ((i : η) → Gs i) :=

/-- Subgroups of torsion-free groups are torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree G → ∀ (H : Subgroup G), Monoid.IsTorsionFree { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Subgroups of additive torsion-free groups are additively torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G],
  AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree G → ∀ (H : AddSubgroup G), AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Quotienting a group by its torsion subgroup yields a torsion free group. -/
theorem ∀ (G : Type u_1) [inst : CommGroup G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree (G ⧸ CommGroup.torsion G) :=

/-- Quotienting a group by its additive torsion subgroup yields an additive torsion free group. -/
theorem ∀ (G : Type u_1) [inst : AddCommGroup G], AddMonoid.IsTorsionFree (G ⧸ AddCommGroup.torsion G) :=

/-- Torsion groups are closed under extensions. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : Group G] {N : Subgroup G} [inst_1 : Group H] {f : G →* H},
  N = MonoidHom.ker f → Monoid.IsTorsion H → Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ N } → Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- Subgroups of torsion groups are torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.IsTorsion G → ∀ (H : Subgroup G), Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Subgroups of additive torsion groups are additive torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup G], AddMonoid.IsTorsion G → ∀ (H : AddSubgroup G), AddMonoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ H } :=

/-- Finite groups are torsion groups. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Finite G], Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- If a group exponent exists, the group is torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G], Monoid.ExponentExists G → Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- A nontrivial torsion-free group is not torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [hN : Nontrivial G], Monoid.IsTorsionFree G → ¬Monoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- The image of a quotient is torsion iff the group is torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : Group G] {N : Subgroup G} [inst_1 : Group H] {f : G →* H},
  Function.Surjective ↑f →
    N = MonoidHom.ker f → Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ N } → (Monoid.IsTorsion H ↔ Monoid.IsTorsion G) :=

/-- The torsion submonoid of an abelian group equals the torsion subgroup as a submonoid. -/
theorem ∀ (G : Type u_1) [inst : CommGroup G], CommMonoid.torsion G = (CommGroup.torsion G).toSubmonoid :=

/-- Additive torsion groups are closed under extensions. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : AddGroup G] {N : AddSubgroup G} [inst_1 : AddGroup H] {f : G →+ H},
  N = AddMonoidHom.ker f → AddMonoid.IsTorsion H → AddMonoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ N } → AddMonoid.IsTorsion G :=

/-- Torsion submonoids are torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : CommMonoid G], Monoid.IsTorsion { x // x ∈ CommMonoid.torsion G } :=

/-- A nontrivial torsion group is not torsion-free. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [hN : Nontrivial G], Monoid.IsTorsion G → ¬Monoid.IsTorsionFree G :=

/-- Quotienting by the torsion submodule gives a torsion-free module. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_2} {M : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] [inst_2 : Module R M],
  Submodule.torsion R (M ⧸ Submodule.torsion R M) = ⊥ :=

/-- The image of a surjective torsion group homomorphism is torsion. -/
theorem ∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Group H] {f : G →* H},
  Function.Surjective ↑f → Monoid.IsTorsion G → Monoid.IsTorsion H :=

/-- Torsion by a set is torsion by the ideal generated by it. -/
theorem ∀ {R : Type u_2} {M : Type u_1} [inst : CommSemiring R] [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid M] [inst_2 : Module R M] (s : Set R),
  Submodule.torsionBySet R M s = Submodule.torsionBySet R M ↑(Ideal.span s) :=

/-- If the direct product of two groups is torsion free then each of the groups is torsion free. -/
theorem
